Sir Edward Burne-Jones 1833-1898 artist lived here 1865-1867

column14: Plaque Info
column16: Plaque More Info

column14: Dame Millicent Garrett Fawcett (1847-1929) Pioneer of women's suffrage lived and died here
column16: Dame Millicent Garrett Fawcett (1847-1929) was an English suffragist and pioneer for women's rights. She was born in Adleburgh, Suffolk to wealthy parents, and through her marriage to an MP, became involved in women's political campaigns. Fawcett was elected president of the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS) in 1890, a position she held until 1919. The NUWSS took a more moderate stance to the suffragettes then their contemporaries, but nevertheless campaigned tirelessly for the vote for women, which was achieved for those over 30, in 1918. Fawcett is considered to be instrumental to this change.

column14: Sir Edward Burne-Jones 1833-1898 artist lived here 1865-1867
column16: Sir Edward Burne-Jones (1833-1898) was a British artist and designer closely associated with the later phase of the Pre-Raphaelite movement. He created a number of famed paintings, as well as stained glass works for several churches. He co-founded Morris, Marshall, Faulkner & Co. with William Morris and other artists associated with the Pre-Raphaelite movement. He also produced many engravings for Morris' Kelmscott Press. With an abiding interest in the decorative arts, Burne-Jones  also designed ceramic tiles, jewellery, tapestries, mosaics and book illustrations, he is considered one of the most influential artists of the 19th century. He lived in Kensington Square for two years, where his daughter Margaret was also born.

column14: Walter Sickert 1860-1942 Painter and etcher lived and worked here
column16: Walter Richard Sickert (1860-1942) was a painter who had an important influence on distinctively British styles of avant-garde art in the 20th century. Sickert was a cosmopolitan and eccentric artist who often favoured ordinary people and urban scenes as his subjects. He often included well-known personalities and images derived from press photographs. Sickert took a keen interest in the crimes of Jack the Ripper, believing he had lodged in a room used by the serial killer- some historians have since claimed that Sickert was the notorious murderer, but this claim has been dismissed by just as many.

column14: Ivor Novello (1893-1951) Composer and Actor Manager lived and died in a flat on the top floor of this building
column16: Ivor Novello (1893-1951) was a composer, actor, theatre manager and singer who became one the most influential British entertainers of the first half of the 20th century. Born into a musical family, his first successes were as a songwriter. His first big hit was Keep The Home Fires Burning, which was enormously popular during WW1. After the war, Novello contributed songs to several successful musical comedies, and wrote complete scores for shows, before turning to acting in the 1920's. Four years after his death the Ivor Novello Awards for song writing were established in his memory.

column14: Bertrand Russell (1872-1970) Philosopher and Campaigner for Peace lived here in flat No.34 1911-1916
column16: Bertrand Russell (1872-1970) was a British philosopher, logician, social critic and campaigner for peace. He was born in Monmouthshire and educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; he made several key contributions to twentieth century mathematics and philosophy, and is considered by many to have led the British 'revolt against idealism'. Russell lived in this house during the First World War, during which time he was prominent in the anti-war movement. Russell established the Russell Tribunal during the Vietnam War, which is now known as the International War Crimes Tribunal.

column14: Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) Clown lived here.
column16: Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) was an English actor and comedian who is best known for his invention of the modern day whiteface clown. He was born into a family of performers, and made his stage debut aged three. As a pantomime clown Grimaldi was considered unsurpassable, his greatest success occurring in 'Harlequin and Mother Goose; or the Golden Egg' at Theatre Royal, Covent Garden. He was an innovator, and his performance as Joey introduced the modern clown to the world. To this day clowns gather annually in full attire at Holy Trinity Church in Dalston, London to celebrate his life.

column14: In 1926 in this house John Logie Baird 1888-1946 first demonstrated television.
column16: John Logie Baird (1888-1946) was a Scottish engineer who is most famous for inventing television. Baird showed ingenuity from an early age, rigging a telephone exchange from his bedroom to communicate with friends from across the street. In the early 1920s Baird made his major breakthrough with transmitting moving images-initially just  silhouettes- but he soon managed  grey, tonal images.  In 1926,  on the top floor of this house in Frith Street he first demonstrated this type of transmission to members of the Royal Institution, and a reporter from the Times newspaper. Baird went on to make major contributions to the development of colour television and broadcasting.

column14: Anna Freud (1895-1982) Pioneer of Child Psychoanalysis lived here 1938-1982
column16: Anna Freud (1895Ð1982) was the sixth and last child of Sigmund and Martha Freud. Born in Vienna, she followed the path of her father and contributed much to the fledgling field of psychoanalysis. Alongside Melanie Klein, she may be considered the founder of psychoanalytic child psychology. Anna moved to Hampstead in 1938 after fleeing Austria, and the harassment of Jews by the Nazis. Much of her important work with children occurred during and immediately after the Second World War, when she observed the effects of stress and lack of parental care on children.

column14: Richard Burton (1925-1984) Actor lived here 1949-1956
column16: Richard Burton (1925-1984) was a Welsh actor who appeared in over seventy films, and was nominated for seven Academy Awards. Born into a working class mining family, he began smoking and drinking at a very young age, both of  which he was notorious for throughout his life. He was a gifted soprano singer and actor and mentored by his schoolmaster, was encouraged to pursue acting as a career. Burton lived in this house while appearing in several British films and stage productions. In 1952 successfully made the transition to Hollywood, becoming for a time its most highly paid actor. In 1963 he appeared with Elizabeth Taylor in Cleopatra, to whom he was famously twice married.

column14: John Lennon (1940-1980) Musician and Songwriter lived here in 1968
column16: John Lennon (1940-1980) was an English musician and songwriter, who rose to worldwide fame in the 1960s as a member of the Beatles, and then as a solo artist in the 1970s.  He is considered to be one of the greatest songwriters of all time, penning some of the most successful pop songs with fellow Beatle Paul McCartney. As well as enjoying immense success as a musician, Lennon also made a significant impact on the anti-war campaign during the Vietnam war. Lennon lived in his house on Montagu Square in 1968, the same year that the Beatles recorded The White Album, following a highly influential visit to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in India. He was killed by a fan outside his New York apartment in 1980.

column14: Sir Henry Wood (1869-1944) Musician lived here
column16: Sir Henry Joseph Wood (1869-1944) was an English conductor best known for his association with London's annual season of classical concerts. Began in 1895, they were to be a season of informal indoor recitals in the style of outdoor 'promenade concerts', where the audience was free to stroll around- the aim being to introduce classical and modern music to a completely new crowd. Wood was appointed as its first conductor, and continued to be for nearly 50 years,  introducing hundreds of new works to British audiences. After his death, the concerts were officially renamed 'The Henry Wood Promenade Concerts' in his honour, but are still commonly referred to as 'The Proms'.

column14: Ralph Vaughan Williams O.M. (1872-1958)Composer lived here from 1953 until his death
column16: Ralph Vaughan Williams (1872-1958) was an English composer of symphonies, chamber music, opera, choral music, and film scores. Educated at Cambridge, and later a pupil of the Royal College of Music, Williams made a considerable contribution to English music. His greatest achievement is considered to be the work for 'The English Hymnal' a collection of hymns in the English language. He also toured the British countryside collecting traditional folk songs and carols, many of which were passed on verbally and otherwise not recorded, so saving many from being lost forever. Williams lived in the house on Hanover Terrace from 1953 until his death five years later.

column14: David Edward Hughes (1831-1900) Scientist and inventor of the microphone lived and worked here
column16: David Edward Hughes (1831-1900) was a British scientist, inventor and musician. He was responsible for some of the most important inventions of the modern age, including the international standard Hughes' Telegraph System. He was the inventor of crystal radio, spark-gap technology and his  pioneering radio work was later built upon by Marconi & Hertz, amongst others. He is best know for inventing the microphone, and which he used in many of his studies and discoveries in the field of radio technology.

column14: Sir George Cayley (1773-1857) Scientist and pioneer of aviation lived here
column16: Sir George Cayley (1773-1857) was a prolific English engineer and a pioneer of aeronautics- he is known as the father of Aerodynamics. Cayley designed the first ever glider to successfully carry a human aloft and discovered and identified the aerodynamic forces of flight: weight, lift, drag and thrust. His findings were key to the Wright Brothers later success. Modern aeroplane design is based on all of those principles, as well as his invention, cambered wings.

column14: Ada Countess of Lovelace 1815-1852 Pioneer of Computing lived here
column16: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace (1815 Ð 1852) was born Augusta Ada Byron, daughter of poet Lord Byron. She was known chiefly for her work on Charles Babbage's early mechanical computer, the Analytical Engine. She was a skilled mathematician, and Babbage called her 'an enchantress of numbers'. Her notes on the engine include what is recognised as the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine; she is considered to be the world's first computer programmer.

column14: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) The pioneer of wireless communication lived here in 1896-1897
column16: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) was an Italian inventor and  businessman. Marconi is often credited as the inventor of radio, commercialising earlier experimentations and ideas of others. He had many successes but it was the transmission of radio signal across the Atlantic for which Marconi is known as a true innovator. Dismissed in Italy, he came to London in 1896 to seek support for his work, so meeting the chief electrical engineer of the Post Office, William Preece- who became one of his most ardent supporters. He lived in this house with his mother during this time.

column14: Eleanor Rathbone (1872-1946) Pioneer of Family Allowances lived here
column16: Eleanor Rathbone (1872-1946) was an independent British Member of Parliament and long-term campaigner for women's rights. Her early life focused on women's political and social rights- including campaigning for an allowance to be paid directly to mothers- which was heavily influenced by her research into the lives of the poor in Liverpool. After WW1 Rathbone continued her lobbying for social reform and grew increasingly- and publicly- concerned with international developments, notably the Spanish Civil War and the nature of Nazi Germany.  Rathbone was instrumental in the introduction of the Family Allowances Act of 1945, which became law just a year before her death.

column14: William Smith (1756-1835) Pioneer of religious liberty lived here
column16: William Smith (1756 Ð 1835) was a leading independent British politician, and was a Member of Parliament (MP) for several constituencies. He was an English Dissenter- religious groups which broke away from the Church of England- and was instrumental in bringing political rights to those groups. He was a friend and close associate of William Wilberforce and a member of the Clapham Sect of social reformers, and was in the forefront of many of their campaigns for social justice, prison reform and philanthropic endeavour- most notably the abolition of slavery. He was the maternal grandfather of pioneer nurse and statistician Florence Nightingale.

column14: Alan Turing (1912-1954) Code-breaker and Pioneer of Computer Science was born here
column16: Alan Mathison Turing (1912ÊÐ 1954) was an EnglishÊmathematician,Êlogician,Êcryptanalyst, andÊcomputer scientist; he  is widely considered to be theÊfatherÊof computer science andÊartificial intelligence. HisÊ'Turing' machine played a significant role in the creation of the modern computer; his work at Bletchley Park during World War Two was critical to the breaking of the German Enigma Code, a key step to winning the war. In 1952-when homosexuality was still illegal-Turing was charged with 'gross indecency', when his relationship with another man became known. Avoiding prison by accepting a course of chemical castration, he died two years later by ingesting Cyanide. In 2009 he received a posthumous public apology from the British Government for his ill-treatment.

column14: George Frideric Handel (1685-1759) Composer lived in this house from 1723 and died here
column16: George Frederic Handel (1685-1759) was a German-British Baroque composer, famous for his operas, oratorios, anthems and organ concertos- he is regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time. His early career was dominated by Italian opera, but it is his English choral work for which he is perhaps best known. These include 'Messiah' and 'Zadok the Priest'. Handel moved to this house in 1723 which he rented for the rest of his life, and which is now a museum to his life and work.

column14: Jimi Hendrix (1942-1970) Guitarist and songwriter lived here 1968-1969
column16: James Marshall 'Jimi' Hendrix (1942-1970) was an American guitarist and singer-songwriter. He is widely considered to be the greatest electric guitarist in music history, and one of the most influential musicians of his era. Hendrix, along with his friend Eric Clapton, was a pioneer of performance and music production, popularising the use of the wah-wah pedal in mainstream rock and the technique of guitar amplifier feedback. Hendrix gained an early and enthusiastic following in London; he lived in a flat here in Brook Street in 1969 with girlfriend Kathy Etchingham.

column14: In a house on this site in 1764-5ÊWolfgang Amadeus MozartÊ1756-1791 lived, played and composed
column16: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) was an Austrian composer, widely recognised as one of the greatest in the history of Western Classical music.  Mozart showed prodigious talent from an early age, touring the Royal Courts of Europe as a child prodigy; he began composing at the age of five. Mozart travelled to London in 1764-5 where he met Johann Christian Bach (youngest son of J S Bach) who was to prove a key influence. Mozart composed over 600 works in many musical genres, including the The Magic Flute.

column14: In this house formerly a Royal residence lived Lord Palmerston (1784-1865) Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary
column16: Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston (1784-1865) known popularly as Lord Palmerston was a British statesman who served twice as Prime Minister in the mid-19th century. Nicknamed 'The Mongoose' he was in office almost continuously from 1807 until his death in 1865, beginning his career as a Tory and ending it as a Liberal. He was a great social reformer, but he is best remembered for his direction of British foreign policy, particularly his attempts to abolish the Slave Trade, when Britain was at the height of its power. He was the most recent British Prime Minister to die in office.

column14: Samuel Morse 1791-1872 American painter, and inventor of the Morse Code lived here 1812-1815
column16: Samuel Finley Breese Morse (1791-1872) was an American painter and inventor. He co-invented Morse code, and was a key contributer in the development of long-range telegraph systems. In 1825, away from home on a painting commission, he was told of his wife's ill health by horse messenger, (at the time the fastest way to carry news). Returning too late, he was heartbroken to learn of her lonely death. He gave up painting, and began to pursue a means of rapid long distance communication. Morse developed a code to be transmitted as a series of dots and dashes,  plus the concept of a single-wire telegraph, to transmit the code. Morse's code was the forerunner to international version still in use today.

column14: Edith Cavell 1865-1915 Pioneer of Modern Nursing in Belgium and Heroine of the Great War trained and worked here 1896-1901
column16: Edith Cavell (1865-1915) was a British nurse and patriot, and was a pioneer of modern nursing in Belgium. During WW1, whilst working as a Red Cross nurse in German-occupied Brussels, Cavell helped over 200 Allied soldiers escape to neutral Holland, from where many returned to Britain. Tricked into confessing, she was arrested by the German forces, tried for treason, and sentenced to death by firing squad, despite great international condemnation. Following her death Cavell has been celebrated as a heroine of the war, and for acting without distinction, nursing wounded soldiers of all sides.  It was here at the former London Hospital that Cavell trained as a nurse.

column14: Jospeh Priestley 1733-1804 Scientist, Philosopher and Theologian was Minister to the Gravel Pit Meeting here in 1793-1794
column16: Joseph Priestley (1733-1804) was an eighteenth century English Dissenting clergyman, theologian, natural philosopher and scientist. He is best known for his discovery in 1774 of oxygen gas, (simultaneously with Antoine Lavoisier but for which he is generally credited). Priestly also invented soda water, and conducted extensive research into electricity. He wrote several papers combining his scientific findings with his religious beliefs, in an attempt to fuse ideas of Enlightenment rationalism with Christian theism. His views were highly controversial and angry mobs forced him to flee overseas, to the USA.

column14: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936) poet and story writer lived here 1889-1891
column16: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936) was an English poet and writer. He is chiefly known for his works of fiction including 'The Jungle Book' and the 'Just So Stories', and is regarded as a major innovator in the art of the short story. Kipling was one of the most popular writers in England at the turn of the 20th  Century, and in 1907 became the youngest recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature. He travelled widely, spending two years at this house in Charing Cross, and where he wrote novels, and stories for several magazines. He was also married in London, in 1892.

column14: William Daniell (1769-1837) Artist and engraver of Indian scenes lived and died here
column16: William Daniell RA (1769Ð1837) was an English landscape and marine painter, and engraver. He travelled extensively in the Far East, producing one of the finest illustrated volumes of the period entitled 'Oriental Scenery'. He also toured the British coastline painting watercolours for the equally ambitious book 'A Voyage Round Great Britain'. His work was much exhibited and in 1822 he became a Royal Academician. Daniell excelled in transferring his pictures to prints using the aquatint technique, which he spent many years  perfecting, and published several successful editions of his works. In 1962 several of his  original plates were re-discovered, and which now belong to the Tate Galleries.

column14: Captain Matthew Flinders, R.N. 1774-1814) Explorer and Navigator lived here
column16: Captain Matthew Flinders (1774-1814) was one of the most successful navigators and cartographers of his age. Inspired by Daniel Defoe's 'Robinson Crusoe' Flinders was the first explorer to circumnavigate Australia, and encouraged the use of that name for the continent, which was previously known as New Holland. Flinders also invented the iron bars commonly used to compensate for the magnetic deviations on board ships; they are now known as Flinders Bars.

column14: John Harrison 1693-1776 inventor of the Marine Chronometer lived and died in a house on this site
column16: John Harrison (1693-1776) was a self-educated carpenter and later a clockmaker. He is most famous for his invention in 1737 of the first reliable marine chronometer. This long-sought device solved the problem of establishing the East-West position (or longitude) of a ship at sea, so revolutionising marine travel in the eighteenth century by safely extending the distances ships could travel, whilst staying on course. Harrison spent his last years in this house in Red Lion Square and is buried in the graveyard of St John's Church, Hampstead.

column14: Site of the business premises of Thomas Earnshaw 1749-1829 noted watch and chronometer maker
column16: Thomas Earnshaw (1749-1829) was an English watchmaker, who is known as a pioneer of Chronometer development. It was Earnshaw who further simplified the production process of the marine chronometer (a device used to measure the east-west position of a ship at sea), making them more affordable, and so available to the general public. An Earnshaw chronometer was used aboard HMS Beagle, during Charles Darwin's 5-year voyage which inspired his theory of evolution.

column14: John Desmond Bernal 1901-1971 Crystallographer lived and died here
column16: John Desmond Bernal (1901-1971) was a British writer, political activist, and physicist best known for his major contributions to X-ray crystallography. At Cambridge University Bernal initiated a research program of X-ray investigations into the structure of complex biological molecules, that resulted in Nobel-level discoveries by his students and co-workers. Bernal also made a significant contributions to the Normandy landings of WWII, comprehensively mapping the coast line, and helping to design an artifical harbour called a Mulberry, which were used extensively in the landings.

column6: Biological Sciences Building, University College, (site of 110) Gower Street
column14: Charles Darwin 1809-1882 Naturalist lived in a house on this site 1838-1842
column16: Charles Robert Darwin (1809-1882) was an English naturalist, and one of the most influential figures in human history. Darwin established that all species of life have descended from common ancestry, proposing the scientific theory of natural selection. He published his theory as 'On The Origin Of Species' in 1859, which is considered the foundation of evolutionary biology. Darwin lived in a house formerly on this site, from 1838-1842; a time when he first conceived his theory, following his 5-year voyage aboard the HMS Beagle.

column14: A.W. Hofmann 1818-1892 Professor of Chemistry lived here
column16: August Wilhelm von Hofmann (1818-1892) was a German chemist. In 1845 Hofmann was appointed the first director of a new school of practical chemistry; it was known as the Royal College of Chemistry and eventually became part of Imperial College London. As well as his considerable contribution to chemistry, Hofmann was the first to introduce molecular models into public lectures around 1860, and his colour scheme is still in use by some chemists today: carbon = black, hydrogen = white, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, chlorine = green, and sulphur = yellow.

column14: Augustus Siebe  1788-1872 Pioneer of the Diving Helmet lived and worked here
column16: Augustus Siebe (1788-1872) was a German-born British engineer known chiefly for his contributions to the diving industry. Siebe moved to London in 1816 where he became in turn a watchmaker, gun maker, instrument maker and finally a mechanical engineer. After being approached in 1830 by the Deane Brothers (inventors of the smoke helmet), Siebe began designing and building diving equipment, producing a helmet fitted to a full length watertight canvas diving suit. This design became standard diving dress which revolutionised underwater civil engineering and  salvage, and commercial and naval diving. He lived and worked at 5 Denmark St.

column14: Ebenezer Howard 1850-1928 Pioneer of the Garden City Movement
column16: Sir Ebenezer Howard (1850-1928) is best known for his 1898 publication (re- printed in 1902 as 'Garden Cities of To-morrow') where he describes a utopian city of people living harmoniously together with nature. Howard's vision was of a self-sufficient city of 32,000 people, on a site of 6000 hectares. It was planned on a concentric pattern with open spaces, public parks and six radial boulevards extending from the centre. The publication resulted in the founding of the garden city movement, that realised several garden cities in Great Britain following the passing of the New Towns Act in 1946. The movement was also greatly influencial in America.

column6: Camden School for Girls, Sandall Road
column14: Frances Mary Buss 1827-1898 Pioneer of Education of Women was Headmistress here 1879-1894
column16: Frances Mary Buss (1827-1894) was an English pioneer of women's education. Buss was at the forefront of campaigns for the endowment of girls' schools, for girls to be allowed to sit public examinations, to enter universities, and for women's rights to vote. The daughter of Robert William Buss and Frances Fleetwood, Buss attended a local free school where she began teaching at the age of fourteen. Buss established the North London Collegiate School for Girls in 1850, followed by Camden School for Girls in 1871, where she was headmistress until her death in 1894.

column14: George Orwell (1903-1950) Novelist and political essayist lived here
column16: Eric Arthur Blair (1903-1950) better known by his pen name George Orwell, was an English novelist and journalist. Considered perhaps the 20th century's best chronicler of English culture, Orwell wrote literary criticism, poetry, fiction and polemical journalism. He is best known for the dystopian novel Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949) and the allegorical novella Animal Farm (1945), which together have sold more copies than any two books by any other 20th-century author. Orwell's influence on popular and political culture endures, and several of his neologisms, along with the term Orwellian Ñ a byword for totalitarian or manipulative social practices Ñ have entered the vernacular.

column14: Ford Madox Brown 1821-1893 Painter lived here
column16: Ford Madox Brown (1821-1893) was an English painter of moral and historical subjects, notable for his distinctly graphic version of the Pre-Raphaelite style. Brown's early work was greatly admired by the young Dante Gabriel Rossetti who asked Brown to tutor him. Although not a member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, Brown remained closely linked to them. Brown's most famous painting is arguably "Work" which attempts to depict the totality of the mid-Victorian social experience in a single image.

column14: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd 1793-1864 Artist who portrayed London lived here
column16: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd (1792 Ð 1864) was a watercolour artist well known for his architectural works. Brother of topographical artist George "Sidney" Shepherd, Thomas was employed to illustrate architecture in London, and later Edinburgh, Bath and Bristol. His paintings were the basis for steel engravings in many books.Shepherd's work, mostly topographical, is characterized by an attention to detail, along with life-like scenes that contained people, carriages and horses. He worked mostly for Frederick Crace, who employed him to paint old London buildings prior to their demolition, with much of the work surviving in the Crace collection at the British Museum

column14: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe 1900-1996 Landscape Architect lived here 1936-1984
column16: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe (1900-1996) was an English landscape architect, garden designer, architect and designer. Jellicoe was born in Chelsea and studied at the Architectural Association in London before travelling to Rome in 1923. It was in Italy that Jellicoe's work on renaissance gardens, which were in a state of decay at that time, inspired much of his landscape architecture. Some of his key design projects included the design of new town Hemel Hempstead in 1947, Ditchley Park in Oxfordshire, Sutton Place in Surrey and the design of the John F Kennedy memorial in Egham, Surrey.

column14: Mary Kingsley (1862-1900) Traveller and ethnologist lived here as a child
column16: Mary Henrietta Kingsley (1862-1900) was an English writer and pioneering explorer of west Africa, who greatly influenced European ideas about Africa and African people. Having lived a sheltered life and never marrying, Kingsley travelled to west Africa following the death of her father George Kingsley.  It was highly unusual for a woman of Kingsley's race, age and gender to embark on such a dangerous journey unaccompanied and despite several close encounters with crocodiles, cannibalistic tribesmen and disease Kingsley's publications and lectures were remarkably modest. She made a significant impact on ideas of the colonialism of Africa. Kingsley died working as a nurse during the Boer War and was interred at sea in accordance with her wishes.

column14: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) Architect lived here 1880-1891
column16: William Richard Lethaby (1857 - 1931) was an English architect and architectural historian whose ideas were highly influential on the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements in architecture, and in the fields of conservation and art education. Born in 1857 at Barnstaple, Lethaby was the son of a carver and gilder. He studied at the local art school and in architects' offices in Barnstaple and Derby, winning the R.I.B.A.'s Sloane Medallion 1879 and the Pugin Studentship 1881. It was  in London that Lethaby founded the Central School of Arts and Crafts, now known as Central St. Martins.

column14: Mahatma Gandhi (1869-1948) stayed here in 1931
column16: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (1869-1948) often referred to as Mahatma Gandhi ("Great Soul") was the pre-eminent political and ideological leader of India during the Indian independence movement. Gandhi's model of non-violent fight for civil rights and freedom that he called 'satyagraha' inspired movements across the world. It was here in 1931 that Gandhi stayed during negotiations between the British government and the Indian nation: Gandhi was the sole representative of the Indian National Congress (INC). The Gandhi-Irwin pact that was signed in March 1931 was effectively a truce, with Gandhi agreeing to end the civil disobedience movement by the INC.

column14: Sir Henry Morton Stanley (1841-1904) Explorer and Writer lived and died here
column16: Sir Henry Morton Stanley (1841-1904) was a Welsh journalist and explorer. Stanley was employed by the founder of the New York Herald Tribune to find the Scottish missionary and explorer David Livingstone who was known to be in Africa but who had not been heard from for some time. The 7000 mile journey through Zanzibar was extremely perilous, but Stanley found Livingstone on 10 November 1871 near Lake Tanganyika and greeted him with the now famous phrase, "Doctor Livingstone, I presume?" Stanley continued to explore the Congo region of Africa until his death in 1904, and his work book "Through the Dark Continent" is considered an inspiration for Joseph Conrad's "Heart of Darkness."

column14: John McDouall Stuart (1815-1866) First Explorer to cross Australia lived and died here
column16: John McDouall Stuart (1815-1866) was a Scottish explorer, and the first man to successfully lead an expedition to traverse the Australian mainland. Born in Scotland in 1815 Stuart trained as civil engineer before emigrating to Australia in 1838. Stuart led a total of six expeditions with the successful south to north journey from Adelaide to Darwin completed in 1862. The town Alice Springs was originally named Stuart in his honour, before being changed in 1933. Stuart died here in London in 1866.

column14: Robert Falcon Scott (1868-1912) Antarctic explorer lived here
column16: Robert Falcon Scott (1868-1912) was a Royal Navy officer and explorer who led two expeditions to the Antarctic regions: the Discovery Expedition, 1901Ð04, and the ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition, 1910Ð13. During this second venture, Scott led a party of five which reached the South Pole on 17 January 1912, only to find that they had been preceded by Roald Amundsen's Norwegian expedition. On their return journey, Scott and his four comrades all perished from a combination of exhaustion, starvation and extreme cold. Scott's exploration of the Antarctic has made his name synonymous with the region, and he is regarded today as a brave and stoic leader.

column14: Edward Adrian Wilson (1872-1912) Antarctic explorer and naturalist lived here
column16: Edward A Wilson (1872-1912) was a polar explorer and expedition artist. Wilson travelled on two Antarctic expeditions: Discovery 1901-1904 and Terra Nova 1910-1912, both under the leadership of Robert Falcon Scott. Wilson developed a love of the countryside and natural history as a young boy, and having studied at Cambridge and in London as a doctor, joined the Discovery expedition as junior surgeon, zoologist and expedition artist. He was Chief of the Scientific Staff of Scott's final expedition. Affectionately known as "Uncle Bill" by the men, Wilson was the confidant of many, respected for his judgement, mediatory skills and dedication to others. By all accounts, Wilson was probably Scott's closest comrade of the expedition.

column14: Charles 3rd Earl Stanhope 1753-1816Reformer and Inventor lived here
column16: Charles Stanhope, 3rd Earl Stanhope aka Charles Mahon, 3rd Earl Stanhope FRS (3 August 1753 Ð 15 December 1816) was a British statesman and scientist. He was the father of the great traveller and Arabist Lady Hester Stanhope and brother-in-law of William Pitt the Younger. Stanhope was an accomplished scientist and inventor, inventing a printing press and lens which both bear his name.

column14: Sir Charles Wheatstone 1802-1875 Scientist and Inventor lived here
column16: Sir Charles Wheatstone (1802-1875) was an English scientist and inventor of many scientific breakthroughs of the Victorian era. As well as inventing the English concertina, the stereoscope and the Playfair cipher (an encryption technique), Wheatstone is perhaps best known for his contributions in the development of the Wheatstone bridge, which is used to measure unknown electrical resistance. He was also a major figure in the development of telegraphy. Following his death, Wheatstone's remains were brought to his house in Regent's Park, before being buried in Kensal Green Cemetery.

column14: Sir Benjamin Count Rumford 1753-1814 Inventor and Adventurer lived here
column16: Sir Benjamin Thompson, Count Rumford (1753-1814) was an American-born British physicist and inventor whose challenges to established theory were part of the nineteenth century revolution in thermodynamics. He also served as a Lieutenant-Colonel in the Loyalist forces in America during the American Revolutionary War. After the end of the war he moved to London where his administrative talents were recognized when he was appointed a full Colonel, and in 1784 received a knighthood from King George III. A prolific designer, he also drew designs for warships.

column14: Dennis Gabor 1900-1979 Physicist and Inventor of Holography lived here
column16: Dennis Gabor (1900-1979) was a Hungarian-British electrical engineer and inventor, most notable for inventing holography, for which he later received the 1971 Nobel Prize in Physics. Holography is the technique used to produce holograms. Gabor was originally from Budapest and studied in Berlin before fleeing Nazi Germany in 1933. Settling in Britain, Gabor moved to London in 1948 to work at Imperial College London where he worked until retirement. Following the rapid development of lasers and a wide variety of holographic applications (e.g., art, information storage, and the recognition of patterns), Gabor achieved acknowledged success and worldwide attention during his lifetime.

column14: Joseph Aloysius Hansom 1803-1882 Architect, founder-editor of 'The Builder' and inventor of the Hansom Cab lived here
column16: Joseph Aloysius Hansom (26 October 1803 Ð 29 June 1882) was a prolific English architect working principally in the Gothic Revival style. As well as an accomplished architect and designer, Hansom invented the Hansom safety cab in 1834; an improved horse-drawn carriage that was fast, light and agile. Hansom also co-founded the eminent architectural journal "The Builder" in 1843 which still publishes today and is one of the oldest business-to-business magazines in the country.

column14: Lord William Thomspon (1824-1907) Physicist and Inventor lived here
column16: William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin (1824-1907) was a mathematical physicist and engineer. At the University of Glasgow he did important work in the mathematical analysis of electricity and formulation of the first and second laws of thermodynamics, and did much to unify the emerging discipline of physics in its modern form. Lord Kelvin is widely known for realising that there was a lower limit to temperature, absolute zero. Absolute temperatures are stated in units of kelvin in his honour. He also carried out significant work on the transatlantic telegraph project. Lord Kelvin spent some time in London and he is interred at Westminster Abbey, close-by the final resting place of Sir Isaac Newton.

column14: John Rae (1813-1893) Arctic explorer lived and died here
column16: John Rae (1813-1693) was a Scottish doctor who explored northern Canada and surveyed parts of the Northwest Passage. Rae studied medicine in Edinburgh before working as a surgeon in Ontario. Rae is perhaps best known for reporting the fate of the Franklin Expedition, a doomed British voyage of Arctic exploration led by Captain Sir John Franklin that departed England in 1845 and became icebound, losing all 128 men. Although Rae gained notoriety for reporting this, he was not as famous as other contemporary explorers, despite being willing to adopt and learn the ways of the indigenous Arctic people.

column14: Sir James Clark Ross (1800-1862) Polar Explorer lived here
column16: Sir James Clark Ross (1800-1862) was a British naval officer and explorer. He explored the Arctic with his uncle Sir John Ross and Sir William Parry, first embarking on a voyage in 1818 in search of the Northwest Passage (a sea route through the Arctic ocean above North America). Ross later led his own expedition to Antarctica in 1839 which charted much of the coastline of the continent. In 1841, James Ross discovered the Ross Sea, Victoria Land, and the volcanoes Mount Erebus and Mount Terror, which were named after the expedition's vessels, and the following year explored the eastern side of what is now known as James Ross Island, discovering and naming Snow Hill Island and Seymour Island.

column14: Sir Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922) Antarctic Explorer lived here
column16: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton (1874-1922) was an Anglo-Irish polar explorer, one of the principal figures of the period known as the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. Gaining valuable experience on RF Scott's Discovery expedition 1901-1904, Shackleton went on to command three voyages of his own. The most famous expedition, Endurance 1914-1916, ended in near-disaster when the vessel became trapped in pack ice and was crushed. There followed a sequence of exploits, and an ultimate escape with no lives lost, thus securing Shackleton's heroic status. He died of a heart attack in 1921 while circumnavigating the Antarctic continent.

column14: In a house on this site lived from 1854-1875 Sir Charles Lyell Geologist and from 1876-1882 W.E. Gladstone Statesman
column16: This building first housed Sir Charles Lyell (1797-1875) a British lawyer who was the foremost geologist of his day. He is best known as the author of Principles of Geology, which popularised James Hutton's concepts of uniformitarianism Ð the idea that the earth was shaped by slow-moving forces still in operation today. Lyell was a close and influential friend of Charles Darwin. Following his death the house was occupied by William Ewart Gladstone (1809-1898). Gladstone was a British Liberal statesman who, in a career lasting over sixty years, served as Prime Minister four times (more than any other person). Gladstone is famous for his oratory, his rivalry with the Conservative leader Benjamin Disraeli and his poor relations with Queen Victoria.

column14: Thomas Young (1773-1829) Man of Science lived here
column16: Thomas Young (1773-1829) was an English polymath, scientist and Egyptologist. He is famous for having partly deciphered Egyptian hieroglyphics (specifically the Rosetta Stone) before Jean-Franois Champollion eventually expanded on his work. He was admired by, among others, Herschel, Helmholtz, Maxwell, and Einstein.Young made notable scientific contributions to the fields of vision, light, solid mechanics, energy, physiology, language, musical harmony and Egyptology. One of the most important contributions to science was to establish the wave theory of light - that light is not a particle, but rather emitted in all directions as a series of waves, rather like sound.

column14: Sir Francis Beaufort 1774-1857 Admiral and Hydrographer lived here
column16: Rear-Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort (1774-1857) was an Irish hydographer and officer in Britain's Royal Navy. Beaufort had a lifelong keen awareness of the value of accurate charts for those risking the seas, having been shipwrecked himself at age fifteen due to a faulty chart, and his life's biggest accomplishments were in nautical charting. As a naval officer Beaufort commanded HMS Woolwich which was tasked with charting the Rio de la Plata estuary of South America. It was during his sea voyages that Beaufort developed the first versions of his Wind Force Scale and Weather Notation coding - now known as the Beaufort scale.

column14: James Smithson 1764-1829 Scientist Founder of the Smithsonian Institution lived here
column16: James Smithson (1764-1829) was a British mineralogist and chemist. Not much is known about Smithson's life as his archive of collections, notebooks, diaries and correspondence was destroyed by fire in 1855 but it is clear that he had a keen interest in minerals and the study of the natural world. He was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1787, then the youngest person to be so. A shrewd investor, Smithson bequeathed a small fortune to the United States of America upon his death to create "an establishment for the increase and diffusion of knowledge among men." It became the Smithsonian Institution.

column14: Major-General William Roy 1726-1790 Founder of the Ordnance Survey lived here
column16: Major-General William Roy FRS (1726 Ð 1790) was a Scottish military engineer, surveyor, and antiquarian. He was an innovator who applied new scientific discoveries and newly emerging technologies to the accurate geodetic mapping of Great Britain. It was Roy's advocacy and leadership that led to the creation of the Ordnance Survey in 1791, the year after his death. His technical work in the establishment of a surveying baseline won him the Copley Medal in 1785. His maps and drawings of Roman archaeological sites in Scotland were the first accurate and systematic study of the subject, and have not been improved upon, even today. Roy was a Fellow of the Royal Society and a member of the Society of Antiquaries of London.

column14: Thomas Henry Huxley 1825-1895 Biologist Lived Here
column16: Thomas Henry Huxley (1825-1895) was an English biologist, known as "Darwin's Bulldog" for his advocacy of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution. Huxley's famous 1860 debate with Samuel Wilberforce was a key moment in the wider acceptance of evolution, and in his own career. He was instrumental in developing scientific education in Britain, and fought against the more extreme versions of religious tradition. In 1869 Huxley coined the term 'agnostic' to describe his own views on theology, a term whose use has continued to the present day. Huxley had little formal schooling and taught himself almost everything he knew. He became arguably the finest comparative anatomist of the latter 19th century.

column14: Sir Ambrose Fleming 1849-1945 Scientist and Electrical Engineer lived here
column16: Sir John Ambrose Fleming (1849-1945) was an English electrical engineer and physicist. As an engineering consultant for firms including Edison Telephone and the Marconi company, Fleming made a significant breakthrough in 1904 when he developed a device he called an "oscillation valve" which soon became known as the Fleming Valve and was an early type of diode. Today, descendants of the original valve (or vacuum tube) still play an important role in a range of applications. They can be found in the power stages of radio and television transmitters, in some high-end audio amplifiers, as detectors of optical and short wavelength radiation, and in sensitive equipment that must be "radiation-hard".

column14: Sir Isaac Newton 1642-1727 Lived Here
column16: Sir Isaac Newton (1642-1727) was an English physicist, mathematician, astronomer, natural philosopher, alchemist, and theologian, who has been "considered by many to be the greatest and most influential scientist who ever lived." Newton's theory of universal gravitation - where motions of objects on Earth and of celestial bodies are governed by the same set of natural laws advanced the Scientific Revolution. Newton lived on Jermyn Street when he was appointed warden of the Royal Mint in 1696; an appointment he took very seriously and campaigned against corruption and inefficiency in the organisation. In 1703, he was elected president of the Royal Society, an office he held until his death.

column14: Hertha Ayrton 1854-1923 Physicist lived here 1903-1923
column16: Hertha Ayrton (1854-1923) was an English engineer, mathematician and inventor. Ayrton was educated at Cambridge at a time when women were only awarded certificates, not degrees by the college; she gained a degree in 1881 from the University of London. She would assist her husband in his experiments in physics and electricity, which led to her own investigations into the electric arc. She was the first woman ever to read a paper before the Institution of Electrical Engineers and was shortly thereafter elected as its' first female member. In 1902 she was rejected as a fellow of the Royal Society, on the grounds that 'married women were not eligible', but was later awarded the Hughes Medal for her research.  Although agnostic, she established the Jewish League for Womens' Suffrage, in 1912.

column14: Leonard Huxley 1860-1933 Julian Huxley1887-1975 Aldous Huxley 1894-1963 Men of Science and Letters lived here
column16: Three members of the great Huxley family lived here: Leonard Huxley (1860-1933) the most prominent son of Thomas Henry Huxley (the scientist and Darwin's greatest supporter), Sir Julian Huxley (1887-1975) and Aldous Huxley (1894-1963). Leonard was a teacher and writer whose major work was a biography of his father. Julian was a prominent zoologist, and was the first Director-General of UNESCO and also the co-founder of the World Wildlife Fund who did much to further Darwin's theory of evolution. Aldous was a novelist of great fame who wrote in an iconoclastic style that was often disenchanted and with a dystopian view, "Brave New World" being the most famous.

column14: SirWilliam Ramsay 1852-1916 Chemist Discoverer of the Noble Gases lived here 1887-1902
column16: Sir William Ramsay (1852-1916) was a Scottish chemist who is most famous for his work in discovering the noble gases. Ramsay was born in Glasgow, Scotland and studied at both Glasgow Academy and the University of Glasgow. After a period in Bristol, Ramsay was appointed chair of Chemistry at University College London in 1887. It was at UCL that his most celebrated discoveries were made - isolating a heavy component of air which did not appear to have any obvious chemical reactivity (he named this "argon"), then neon, krypton, xenon and helium discoveries in the following years. He received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1904.

column14: Sir William Crookes 1832-1919 Scientist lived here from 1880 until his death
column16: Sir William Crookes (1832-1919) was a British chemist and physicist who attended the Royal College of Chemistry in London and who was a pioneer of vacuum tubes, inventing the Crookes tube. Crookes was born in London and rose to prominence as a chemist in the 1850s, working under AW Hofmann. It was at 7 Kensington Gardens, Crookes's home, that much of his most notable work was done. As well as discovering the chemical element thallium, Crookes also pioneered the use of vacuum tubes; he developed the Crookes radiometer becoming one of the first scientists to investigate what are known today as plasmas.

column14: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) Scientist and Statesman First President of the State of Israel lived here
column16: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) was a scientist and politician who became the first President of the State of Israel in 1949. Weizmann was born in Russia and studied in Switzerland before moving to Britain to become lecturer of Chemistry at the University of Manchester. During WWI he was credited with developing a method of producing acetone from maize; which was needed for the production of artillery shells. It was in London that Weizmann was successful in procuring from Arthur James Balfour the Balfour Declaration of 1917 in which the British government supported the creation of a Zionist state in Palestine.

column14: Sir Norman Lockyer 1836-1920 Astronomer, Physicist and Founder of Nature lived here 1876-1920
column16: Norman Lockyer (1836-1920) was an English scientist and astronomer. It was in the 1860s that Lockyer became fascinated with electromagnetic spectroscopy (the study of the interaction between matter and radiated energy). Working in London, Lockyer observed an unknown element emitted from the sun which he named "helium" from the Greek word "Helios" meaning sun. As well as his astronomical work, Lockyer also founded the journal "Nature" in 1869, to facilitate the transmission of ideas between scientists.

column6: The Elms, 29-32 Clapham Common North Side
column14: Sir Charles Barry (1795-1860) Architect lived and died here
column16: Sir Charles Barry (1795-1860) was an English architect who is best known for his role in the rebuilding of the Palace of Westminster, also known as the Houses of Parliament. Barry travelled extensively throughout Europe and the Middle East from 1817-1820, before working for the Church Commissioners in the Gothic Revival architecture style. Barry made a significant contribution to the Italian Renaissance garden fashions of Victorian Britain, inspired by his travels. Barry's most significant work was the design of the Palace of Westminster after it was destroyed by fire in 1834. He also remodelled Trafalgar Square. Barry lived in Clapham until his death in 1860.

column14: John Francis Bentley (1839-1902) Architect lived here
column16: John Francis Bentley (1839-1902) was an English ecclesiastical architect. Bentley was born in Doncaster and trained as an architect in the offices of Henry Clutton. Bentley's most imporant commission was that of the Westminster Cathedral in 1894. As he had mastered the neo-Gothic and Byzantine Revivalist styles thoughout his career, Bentley decided to travel to Italy to study some of the most important Byzantine-influenced cathedrals, such as St Mark's Basilica in Venice, which provided much of the inspiration for Westminster Cathedral.

column14: Lancelot 'Capability' Brown 1716-1783 Landscape Architect lived here 1764-1783
column16: Lancelot "Capability" Brown (1716-1783) was a pioneering landscape architect. Brown began his career at Stowe, Buckinghamshire, under William Kent, one of the founders of the new English style of landscape garden. As a proponent of this style, Brown became quickly sought after by families all over the country. Brown was coined "Capability" because he would often tell his clients that their estates had great "capability" for improvement. It is estimated that Brown worked on over 170 gardens,  and in 1764 he was appointed master gardener at Hampton Court Palace. He is today regarded as "England's greatest gardener."

column14: William Butterfield 1814-1900 Architect lived here
column16: William Butterfield (1814-1900) was an English architect who was a pioneer of the Gothic Revivalist style during the Victorian era. Butterfield was born to non-conformist parents in London and after training with several notable architects he set up his own practice in 1840. Butterfield's style was heavily influenced by the Cambridge Camden Society, of which he was a member, who promoted the study of Gothic Architecture. Butterfield was also famous for his use of polychromy (the multiple use of colours in brickwork) which can be seen in his design of Rugby School in Warwickshire and Keble College at Oxford.

column14: Colen Campbell (1676-1729) Architect lived and died here
column16: Colen Campbell (1676-1729) was a pioneering Scottish architect. Having initially trained as a lawyer in Edinburgh, Campbell decided to move to London to train as an architect. His highly influential published work "Vitruvius Britannicus" which appeared in three volumes between 1715 and 1725 was instrumental in popularising the neo-Palladium style which came to dominate early eighteenth century architecture. Under the guidance of Lord Burlington, Campbell worked on buildings such as the Royal Academy in London and Stourhead in Wiltshire. Campbell is widely credited as one of the founders of the Georgian style of architecture.

column6: Central School of Arts and Crafts, Southampton Row
column14: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) Architect and first principal of this school in 1896-1911
column16: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) was an English architect whose ideas were influential on the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements. In 1894 Lethaby was appointed Art Inspector to the Technical Education Board of the newly formed London County Council. Here he had a pioneering role in developing education in the fine and practical arts, most notably as the founder of the Central School of Arts and Crafts in 1896. His most significant innovations lay in breaking down academic barriers between design (perceived as an artistic and intellectual pursuit) and production (widely perceived as the less sophisticated activity of the craftsman or artisan). Lethaby believed that this was an artificial distinction and sought to have both taught as equally valuable parts of the process of producing a high quality end-product.

column14: Frank Matcham 1854-1920 Theatre Architect lived here 1895-1904
column16: Frank Matcham (1854-1920) was a pioneering English architect who desgned over 200 theatres throughout Britain between 1890-1915. Matcham inherited his father-in-law's architectural practice in 1878, from where his most famous designs were made - these include the Hackney Empire, London Coliseum and the Victoria Palace theatre. By the outbreak of the First World War no significant town was without its theatre or music hall. Matcham's success lay in his innovative steel cantilevers which, when used in constructing the theatre space, allowed balconies to be built without pillars, thus improving sight lines for the audience. He also set new standards in safety and his work was extremely popular with the public.

column14: Here lived and died John Loughborough Pearson 1817-1897 and later Sir Edwin Landseer Lutyens 1869-1944 Architects
column16: Two pioneering architects of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries lived in this house. The first inhabitant was John Loughborough Pearson (1817-1897) who was one of the foremost Gothic Revivalist architects of the late-Victorian era. He was renowned for his work on churches and cathedrals in Britain, including a proficiency for the art of vaulting. His most famous work is Truro Cathedral. He lived for much of his life in Mansfield Street, London, and was awarded the RIBA gold medal in 1880. The second inhabitant was Edwin Lutyens (1869-1944) who was an English architect and designer. Through a long industrious career Lutyens contributed much to the architecture of the British nation and Commonwealth and is often referred to as "the greatest English architect of all time." Born in London in 1869, Lutyens studied at what is now the Royal College of Art before starting his own practice in 1885. Lutyens is closely associated with the commemoration of the First World War through his designs, most notably the Cenotaph in Whitehall. Lutyens was also commissioned to design New Delhi, which was chosen to replace the seat of the British Indian government in 1912 and is known today as "Lutyens Delhi."

column14: Red House built in 1859-1860 by Philip Webb, architect for William Morris poet and artist who lived here 1860-1864
column16: Red House in Bexleyheath is one of the most important buildings in the history of the Arts and Crafts movement and of nineteenth century architecture. It was designed by William Morris and Philip Webb in 1859 as a home for Morris and his wife Jane. The house was designed to be a "palace of art" for Morris and his friends; the windows and wall paintings were created by Edward Burne-Jones, a fellow pre-Raphaelite. Morris and his family lived for only five years in Red House and were forced to sell for financial reasons. Now owned by the National Trust the house is preserved to give an insight into the truly iconic work of its designers and artists of the time.

column14: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (1880-1960) Architect designed this house and lived here 1926-1960
column16: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (1880-1960) was an English architect. Scott is responsible for the design of the some of 20th century Britain's most iconic and famous buildings. His first major commission was the design of the Liverpool Anglican Cathedral when he was 21 years old - the project would last his lifetime. Scott also designed Battersea Power Station which was completed in 1933. As well as significant work in architecture, Scott was also responsible for the design of the red telephone box. Again winning another competition, this time for the General Post Office, Scott's 'Kiosk No. 2' with its unique domed roof and bright red design was installed in every town and village in the country. Scott designed and lived in his house in Paddington from 1926 until his death in 1960.

column14: Luke Howard (1772-1864) Namer of clouds lived and died here
column16: Luke Howard (1772-1864) was a British manufacturing chemist and an amateur meteorologist. As well as running a successful pharmaceutical business, Howard was a passionate amateur meteorologist. From 1801 he made comprehensive recordings of the weather and these inspired his essay 'Essay on the Modification of Clouds' in 1803. It was in this publication that Howard first proposed the three principal categories of clouds: cumulus, stratus and cirrus, as well as several sub-categories. His work was of significant impact on the study of weather and despite having no formal scientific education is known today as the 'father of meteorology'.  He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society on 8 March 1821.

column14: Thomas Henry Wyatt 1807-1880 Architect lived and died here
column16: Thomas Henry Wyatt (1807-1880) was an Irish British architect who had a prolific and distinguished career, being elected President of the Royal Institute of British Architects in 1870 and awarded their Royal Gold Medal in 1873. He lived and practised in Great Russell Street until his death in 1880. Wyatt is famous for designing many buildings of the nineteenth century, in styles ranging from Italianate to Gothic, including the Knightsbridge Barracks and Kensington Palace Gardens. Some of the most prominent architects of the 18th and 19th centuries were members of Wyatt's family.

column14: Sir Christopher Wren 1632-1723 Architect lived here
column16: Sir Christopher Wren (1632-1723) was an English astronomer, geometer and mathematician-physicist, and one of the most acclaimed architects of all time. Wren is widely associated with the major rebuilding programme following the Great Fire of London in 1666, which included St Paul's Cathedral in the City of London. Wren was also responsible for the design of the south front of Hampton Court Palace, Greenwich Naval College, Kensington Palace and the library at Trinity College, Cambridge. Wren was also part of the formation of the Royal Society of which he was President from 1680 to 1682. Wren was resident of Hampton Court during the extensive restoration commissioned by King William III and Queen Mary II in 1689.

column14: Alfred Waterhouse 1830-1905 Architect lived here
column16: Alfred Waterhouse (1830 Ð 1905) was a British architect, particularly associated with the Victorian Gothic Revival architecture. He is known for designing a wide variety of other buildings throughout the country and perhaps most famous for designing the Natural History Museum in London, and Manchester Town Hall. Financially speaking, Waterhouse was probably the most successful of all Victorian architects. Though expert within Neo-Gothic, Renaissance revival, and Romanesque revival styles, he never limited himself to a single architectural style. Waterhouse designed and lived in his house on New Cavendish Street, London.

column14: C.F.A. Voysey 1857-1941 Architect and Designer lived here
column16: CFA Voysey (1857-1941) was an English architect and furniture and textile designer. Voysey began his career designing wallpaper and fabrics in the 1880s, and his style was influenced by the Arts and Crafts Movement, led by William Morris. Later, he concentrated on architecture, and was unusual for designing every aspect of a house, including the furniture. He was concerned with form and function, and shunned ornamental complexities that were popular at the time. Such was Voysey's influence in the 1920s and 1930s he is often credited as being a pioneer of modern architecture, - by eliminating detail and celebrating simplification of form.

column14: Michael Ventris 1922-1956 Architect and Decipherer of Linear B script lived here
column16: Michael Ventris (1922-1956) was an English architect and classical scholar who had a prodigious gift for languages. He is most famous for his deciphering of Linear B, an early form of Greek known as 'Mycenaean Greek', which was discovered inscribed on tablets in modern-day Crete by Sir Arthur Evans. Ventris was awarded an OBE in 1955 for 'services to Mycenaean palaeography', in recognition of the significance of his work. A few years after deciphering Linear B in 1951-1953, Ventris, who lived in Hampstead, died in a car crash, aged 34.

column14: Thomas Smith Tait (1882-1954) Architect lived here
column16: Thomas Smith Tait (1882-19545) was a prominent Scottish Modernist architect, who designed a number of Art Deco buildings. Having attended Glasgow School of Art, Tait was recruited by prestigious architects John Burnet & Sons in 1902; he became a partner in 1918. It was at the practice that Tait produced his most notable works including the pylons for Sydney Harbour Bridge, St Andrew's House in Edinburgh and the later phases of Selfridge's, London. He also designed several modernist houses in St John's Wood as well as war memorials following the First World War. Tait lived in Gates House in Hampstead from 1928 which he tactfully extended and modernised,  fitting it out with Art Deco features.

column14: Sir Robert Smirke (1831-1912) Architect lived here
column16: Sir Robert Smirke (1780-1867) was an English architect famous for his Greek Revivalist style. Like many architects of his time, Smirke was greatly influenced by the buildings and palaces he visited during his 'Grand Tour' of Europe during 1801-1805. The largest and best known of Smirke's buildings is the main block and faade of London's British Museum, which he was invited to design in 1820. The main facade of the Museum and its great colonnade of 44 Greek iconic columns, are loosely based on those of Athena Polias at Priene-the ancient Greek city of Ionia- which he visited during his tour.

column14: Dante Gabriel Rossetti 1828-1882 poet and painter and Algernon Charles Swinburne 1837-1909 poet lived here
column16: Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-1882) was a British painter and poet, and co-founder of the celebrated Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood group of artists. His work was highly influential, particularly on his contemporaries William Morris and Edward Burne Jones. After the death of his wife and muse Lizzie Siddal, Rossetti moved into this house where he lived for twenty years, surrounding himself with extravagant furnishings and exotic animals and birds, eventually becoming a recluse. Several of his paintings now belong to the Tate Gallery. For a time he lived here with his friend, the celebrated writer Algernon Charles Swinburne.

column14: Sir Robert Peel 1750-1830 Manufacturer and reformer and his son Sir Robert Peel 1788-1850 Prime Minister Founder of the Metropolitan Police lived here
column16: Sir Robert Peel (1788-1850) was a British Conservative statesman who twice served as Prime Minister in the early-mid  19th Century. As Home Secretary, he formed the Metropolitan Police Force in 1829, which became the model of modern policing throughout the country. Police officers were affectionately nicknamed 'Bobbies' in his honour, and are often still called so today. Although unpopular at first, the constables proved successful at cutting crime. He lived here with his father Sir Robert Peel (1750-1830) who was a British politician and industrialist, and one of the early textile manufacturers of the Industrial Revolution.

column14: Sir Robert Walpole 1676-1745 Prime Minister and his son Horace Walpole 1717-1797 Connoisseur and Man of Letters lived here
column16: Sir Robert Walpole (1676-1745) was a British statesman who is generally regarded as the first Prime Minister of Great Britain. Such was his influence in the Cabinet and the politics of his day he was gifted 10 Downing Street by King George II; it remains the HQ of the British Government today. His strategy of keeping Great Britain at peace in an historically unsettled period contributed greatly to its prosperity at the time. He lived here with his son Horace (1717-1797), who is best known for his building of Strawberry Hill in Twickenham.

column14: Here lived Philip Henry Gosse 1810-1888 Zoologist Sir Edmund Gosse 1849-1928 Writer and Critic born here
column16: Philip Henry Gosse (1810 Ð 1888) was an English naturalist and populariser of natural science; he is considered the inventor of the seawater aquarium, and an innovator in the study of marine biology. He was also a preacher and wrote the work entitled 'Omphalos' which attempted to reconcile the geological ages with biblical account of creation. He lived in De Beauvoir Town throughout his career, and it was from here that he regularly travelled abroad to study, and develop his theories and writings. He lived here with his son Edmund who famously wrote his memoir  'Father & Son', a powerful tale of late victorian life.

column14: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) wit and dramatist lived here
column16: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) was an Irish writer and poet. He was one of the best known figures of the late-Victorian era, famous for his plays, biting wit and flamboyant character. He wrote some of the best-loved and endearing plays and books such as  'The Importance of Being Earnest', and 'The Picture of Dorian Gray' and children's books 'The Selfish Giant' and 'The Happy Prince'. In 1895, at the height of his fame he attempted to bring a libel case against the father of his male lover, but which ultimately led to his own arrest and trial for gross indecency. He was imprisoned for two years' hard labour; upon his release he fled to Paris where he died destitute, in 1900.

column14: In this house occupied by Thomas Davies, bookseller, Dr. Samuel Johnson first met James Boswell in 1765
column16: Samuel Johnson (1709-1784) was a writer, poet and essayist who made lasting contributions to English literature. His work 'A Dictionary of the English Language' was published in 1755. It took him nine years to complete and was considered one of the greatest single achievements of scholarship. It was unsurpassed for 150 years, when the 'Oxford English Dictionary' was introduced. This house was occupied by Thomas Davies (1712-1785) a bookseller and author,  and it was he that first introduced Dr Johnson to James Boswell (1740-1795), at this address. Boswell wrote 'The Life of Samuel Johnson' which is regarded as the greatest biography in the English language.

column14: Sir Marc Isambard Brunel 1769-1849 and Isambard Kingdom Brunel 1806-1859 civil engineers lived here
column16: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806-1859) was a victorian civil engineer, regarded as one of the most pioneering and important in history. Brunel learnt much from his father, assisting in the building of the Thames Tunnel from Rotherhithe to Wapping. He built the first major British railway- the Great Western Railway- which ran from London to Bristol, and designed numerous bridges, tunnels and  transatlantic steamships. Although not all of his projects were successful, they contained innovative solutions to long-standing problems and his designs revolutionised public transport and modern engineering. He lived here in this house with his father, notable engineer Sir Marc Isambard Brunel .

column14: James Glaisher 1809-1909 Astronomer, Meteorologist and pioneer of weather forecasting lived here
column16: James Glaisher (1809-1903) was a English meteorologist and aeronaut, but is most famous as a pioneering balloonist. between 1862-1866 Glaisher made numerous ascents to measure the atmosphere's humidity and temperature at its highest levels. His ascent on September 5th 1862 broke the world record for altitude, but he passed out at around 8,800 metres before a reading could be taken; estimates suggest it may have been as high as 10,900 metres (2,052 metres higher than Mt Everest). Glaisher was a founder member of the Meteorological Society, and worked at the Royal Greenwich Observatories from 1835-1869.

column14: Frank Pick 1878-1941 Pioneer of Good Design for London Transport lived here
column16: Frank Pick (1878-1941) was a British transport administrator, who became one of the most important commissioners of art in Britain. Pick rose through the corporate ranks of the Underground Electric Railway Company of London (UERL) to become managing director in 1928. Early in his career he began work on developing a strong brand identity and visual style for which the London Underground is now famous. From standardisation of signage, to commissioning the Johnston 'Underground' typeface, Pick was responsible for creating some of the most iconic imagery of London's transport system, and in the history of graphic design.

column14: Gavin Turk sculptor worked here 1989-1991
column16: Gavin Turk (1967-present) is a British artist and sculptor. He is often associated with the loose group of visual artists, the Young British Artists (YBAs). Turk gained notoriety in 1991 when, as his submission for his MA show at the Royal Academy of Art, he unveiled 'Cave' which consisted of a whitewashed wall with a single blue plaque that read: 'Gavin Turk, Sculptor worked here 1989-1991'. Famously, Turk's tutors refused to award him a degree, but it brought him to the attention of the influential  art collector  Charles Saatchi. Ironically Turk commemorated himself before his career had truly begun, yet paradoxically launched his career at the same time and  is now commemorated with a genuine blue plaque.

column14: Charles Dickens 1812-1870 Novelist lived here
column16: Charles Dickens (1812-1870) was an English writer who is regarded as the greatest novelist of the Victorian period; he was responsible for some of English literature's most iconic stories and characters. Thrust into poverty at an early age, Dickens drew much inspiration for his novels 'Great Expectations' and 'David Copperfield' from the appalling conditions he experienced working in a factory as a boy. His work has never been out of print and his novel 'A Christmas Carol' has sold over 200 million copies since its publication in 1859. Dickens and his family lived at 48 Doughty Street from 1837 to 1839, and it was here that his sister-in-law Mary died in his arms after a brief illness - his memories of her inspired several characters in his novels, notably Little Nell in 'The Old Curiosity Shop'.

column14: Sir Robert Wigram, MP, 1744-1830 High Sheriff of Essex Merchant lived here
